page.title: 05ECOLOGY OF ABINGTON GARDENS
page.content: birds - starling, thrush, dunnock, sparrows and robins - the robins have nested nearby. We often hear a tawny owl. Hedgehogs and toads come to our garden at night. The toad lays eggs in our pond but the fish eat them. Aconites,hairy violets, and lords and ladies grow near our house. The most common butterflies in our garden are the peacock and cabbage white. Tortoiseshell and orange tip butterflies visit our garden with ladybirds, bees and wasps. A violet ground beetle also comes to our garden. New sycamore and beech trees will grow in place of elms and larch. The new trees will make new homes for squirrels and birds.
